reasoning: Crucial because the paper’s main optimistic pathway (§3) relies on partial AM-convergence; if even that fails under antirealism, the recommended focus shifts substantially toward lock-in shaping and worst-case safeguards. Highly paper-specific: it directly targets §2.4.2’s antirealism/free-parameters argument and stress-tests the paper’s explicit ~1-in-a-million enabling assumption for trade-based optimism. Tractability is moderate-low: you can gather indirect evidence (e.g., empirical work on value divergence under reflection, computational/agent-based models of idealisation dynamics, eliciting stability of de-dicto motivations under enhancement/AI-advice scenarios), but the core claim depends on hard-to-operationalise counterfactuals about post-AGI reflective processes and metaethics. Clarity is decent but hampered by ambiguities in “reflective processes,” “good de dicto maximizers,” “actionable sense,” and the exact operational meaning of “power-weighted” and the 1e-6 threshold. Decision hook is explicit with clear strategy forks. Dead weight is low: the anchor and implications mostly serve to pin down why the question matters.
title: Does moral anti-realism undermine even partial convergence on altruistic goals?
